questions.text: A young woman working in the printing industry is likely to suffer from infertility due to which of the following toxicity?
questions.solution:
A woman working in the printing industry is likely to suffer from infertility due to lead toxicity. 

More industrial workers are exposed to lead than to any other toxic metal. Occupational exposure to lead is seen in several industries including the manufacture of storage batteries, glass,  shipbuilding,  printing, potteries, and rubber industries. 

The effects of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, blue-line on the gums, stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist & foot drop,  headache, and convulsions. In young or pregnant women, prolonged lead exposure can cause miscarriages, stillbirth, premature births, etc.

questions.text: Which amongst the following can be used to treat kesari dal toxicity?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism (kesari dal toxicity).

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram or Bengal gram. It is mostly consumed by poor agricultural laborers because it is relatively cheap. Lathyrism is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour). 

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

questions.text: The recent Air Quality Index (AQI) in Delhi was reported to be 250. Which of the following parameters is included in the calculation of AQI?
questions.solution:
Lead is likely to be elevated as it is the only parameter considered out of the given options while calculating the AQI.

Air Quality Index (AQI) is a tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and colour that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI - 

  • PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  • PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  • NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  • SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  • CO (Carbon monoxide)
  • O3 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  • NH3 (Ammonia)
  • Pb (Lead)

AQI categories and the range are as follows :

AQI Category AQI Range
Good 0 - 50
Satisfactory 51 - 100
Moderately polluted 101 - 200
Poor 201 - 300
Very poor 301 - 400
Severe 401 - 500

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

  • The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.
  • Air pollutants:
Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide From incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulphur dioxide Colorless gas with a sharp odor. Results from combustion of sulphur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc. It is one of the main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources.
Carbon dioxide Increase in global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog.
Cadmium Results from volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc.
Hydrogen sulphide Produced in waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc.
Ozone Ground level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen  Most common form is nitric oxide. Produced from coal burning, road traffic and electricity generation. Affects lungs adversely.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Produced by incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc. PAHs are carcinogenic and mutagenic.
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter. Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon and water.
  • Common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, PAHs, nitrogen and sulphur oxides, pesticides, asbestos, lead, radon and other biological pollutants. Most these are from coal or fuel combustion. Pollutants like radon, lead, asbestos, etc. are from construction materials, paints and demolition.
  • Effects of indoor air pollution:
    • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
    • Stroke
    • Ischemic heart disease
    • COPD
    • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
    • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight
  • Indicators of air pollution:
    • Sulphur dioxide is one of the best indicators of air pollution
    • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
    • Grit and dust measurement are another indicator of air pollution
    • Co-efficient of haze is a factor used in assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosol in air
    • Air pollution index is an arbitrary index which takes into account one or more pollutants as a measure of pollution severity
    • Suspended particle matter (SPM) is another indicator widely used
  • In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: According to the  updated VVM guidelines on the oral Rotavac vaccine , which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Vaccine Vial Monitor for Rotavac is located on the label of the vaccine vial
Open vial policy applies to both the old and new products of the Rotavac vaccine
Vaccine schedule has been changed to a 2-dose schedule at 6 weeks and 10 weeks
Rotavac must be stored at -25°C to -10°C at the district level and 2°C to 8°C at the sub-district level

questions.solution:
Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) has updated VVM guidelines on the oral Rotavac vaccine to change the location of the Vaccine Vial Monitor(VVM), which was initially on the cap of the vial, to the label of the vaccine vial.

The open vial policy is applicable only to this new product of the Rotavac vaccine. Implementation of the Open Vial Policy allows the reuse of partially used multi-dose vials of applicable vaccines under the universal immunization policy to prevent wastage of medication.

The vaccine schedule will remain the same, that is a 3-dose schedule at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks. It is to be stored at -15°C to -25°C  till district stores and then at 2°C to 8°C at the sub-district level.

questions.text: The given logo belongs to which of the following programmes?

choices.text: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), which was earlier called the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

NPCDCS was launched in 2010 in order to prevent and control major NCD (non-communicable diseases). It focuses on strengthening infrastructure, human resource development, health promotion, early diagnosis, management, and referral.

Under NPCDCS, NCD Clinics are being set up at District and CHC levels, to provide services for early diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for common NCD. NPCDCS has specialized facilities at the district hospital level. At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral are done.

The NPCDCS has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states. For the cancer component, there is the Tertiary Care Cancer Centers (TCCC) scheme, which aims at setting up/strengthening State Cancer Institutes (SCI) and TCCCs all over the country, for providing comprehensive cancer care in the country. 

Note: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with this programme in 2021.

Other options:

Option A: The logo below shows Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram

Option C: The logo below shows Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission

Option D: The logo below shows Family Planning Campaign

questions.text: Nayi Pahel kits are distributed to newly wedded couples under the family planning programme. Which of the following items is present in the kit?
questions.solution:
Urine pregnancy kits are present in the Nayi Pahel kits distributed to newly wedded couples for a subsidised fee of Rs 220 under the family planning programme - Mission Parivar Vikas. 

It is a family planning kit consisting of -

  • Jute bag with the family planning programme logo
  • Marriage registration form
  • A pamphlet containing information on contraception, family planning, how to use UPT kits and ASHA schemes
  • Pack of 3 male condom(Nirodh) x 2 units
  • Mala-N oral contraceptive pills x 2 packs
  • 3 emergency contraceptive pills called E pills
  • 2 pregnancy testing kits
  • A grooming or hygiene kit consisting mirror, lipstick, bindi, etc 
  • An information card with details on respective ASHAs and nearest ANMs

The ASHA is incentivized 100/kit distributed to newly wedded couples.

Antara (Intramuscular injectable contraceptive-DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas but are not part of the Nayi Pahel kits.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

The Chi-square statistic is a non-parametric (distribution-free) test designed to analyze group differences when the dependent variable is measured at a nominal level.

This statistical test can be used to determine whether the antibiotic was effective or not. The outcome of this study would be either "the antibiotics cured the disease" or "the antibiotics did not cure the disease". Hence this study is having two qualitative variables. Qualitative data, also known as “categorical data,” is defined by a category and grouped by characteristics and are then given a name rather than by a measured numeric expression.

If this study were to study the effect of antibiotics in terms of the growth of bacteria in culture, such as the number of colony-forming units grown with each antibiotic, the study would have quantitative/parametric variables. Then other tests like t-test or ANOVA would be used.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: The standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, tremors, and vomiting. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The rice farmer presents with features of acute encephalitis and non-specific features like fever, cough, and diarrhea, and is most likely suspected to have Japanese encephalitis. The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquito due to unspotted wings and hunched back, which is a vector of Japanese encephalitis. 

Culex mosquitoes:

They are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

In the larval stage, they are suspended with heads downwards at an angle, a siphon tube is present, and there is an absence of palmate hairs. They lay the eggs in clusters, and adult mosquitoes have their wings unspotted with hunched back.

Various mosquito larvae are shown in the image below. Siphon tube is present in Aedes and Culex, whereas, it is absent in Anopheles.

 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds. Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs. Ultra-low-volume fogging is a method of insecticide application where a small volume (<500 ml/hectare) of liquid insecticide is applied to provide maximum killing of disease vectors.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus is shown below:

Other options:

Option A: Anopheles mosquito is the vector for malaria.

Option B: Anopheles mosquito/Mansoni Mosquito could be the vectors for filariasis.

Option C: Aedes mosquito is the vector for yellow fever.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: The Sparsh campaign was launched to spread awareness about which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of anti-leprosy day (observed on the last Sunday of January) to promote awareness about leprosy.

Objectives of SLAC are to create mass awareness in the community on leprosy, to reduce stigma and discrimination in the community and for early detection of Leprosy cases. 

Sapna refers to a local school-going girl who will help to spread awareness in the community.

The other developments under NLEP are:

  • Mycobacterium Indicus Prani (MiP) vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts (it is in a project mode).
  • Nikusth: A web-based system for the data management of leprosy cases.

Note: Meena is a nine-year-old girl, who is the symbol of UNICEF's Girl Empowerment programme to impart important messages on gender, child rights, education, health and development in the South Asian region.

The posters below depict the role play by Sapna:

World Leprosy Day is celebrated on 30 January. This international day is an opportunity to celebrate people who have experienced leprosy, raise awareness of the disease, and call for an end to leprosy-related stigma and discrimination. The “United for Dignity” campaign calls for unity in honoring the dignity of people who have experienced leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correlation coefficient (R) of the given scattergram?
questions.solution:
The given scattergram demonstrates a strong negative correlation between the X and Y variables. The correct correlation coefficient (R) value in this case would be -0.9.

A scattergram is a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along the two axes. Each point on the graph signifies a pair of values from the same observation. The pattern of the resulting points reveals if any correlation exists. A scattergram with positive correlation (R-value > 0) means high values of one variable are associated with high values of another variable. One with a negative correlation (R-value < 0) means high values of one variable are associated with low values of the other variable.

In the given graph, the data points show increasing values on the x-axis correspond with decreasing values on the y-axis and vice-versa (negative correlation). The “line of best fit” for the given scattergram will have data points closer to the line, demonstrating a strong negative correlation (R-value closer to -1).

 

Determining a correlation coefficient (R) involves finding the “line of best fit” (an imaginary straight line) to the plotted data points. The closer the data points to this straight line, the stronger the linear correlation between the two variables.

Other options: 

Option A: R-value of +0.3 is a weak positive correlation (R-value > 0, closer to 0 than 1), as shown below.

 

Option B: R-value of +1 is a strong positive correlation (R-value > 0, closer to 1 than 0), as shown below.

 

Option C: R-value of -0.4 is a weak negative correlation (R-value < 0, closer to 0 than 1), as shown below.

questions.text: The modified Kuppuswamy scale for socio-economic status uses ______

choices.text: Income of family, monetary value of material possessions, education
Income of family, education and occupation of head of family
Income of family, education of members of family, monetary value of material possessions
Education and occupation of head of family, number of members in family

questions.solution:
The modified Kuppuswamy scale used income of the family, education and occupation of head of family.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a case-control study and employs matching to select controls similar to the cases. Which of the following types of bias is likely to be reduced as a result?
questions.solution:
Matching controls to be similar to the cases is likely to reduce confounding bias or bias due to confounding factors.

A confounding factor is one that is related to both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Irrespective of being associated with the exposure under study, the confounding factor might itself serve as a risk factor for the disease. Hence, the elimination of these confounding factors is essential before carrying out a case-control study. 

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (such as a case-control study), is the process where the participants in two groups (cases and controls in this case) are matched based on factors that are known to influence the outcome of disease (such as age, gender, race, etc.) to stop the potential confounders from distorting the results.

Other strategies to eliminate confounding factors include randomization, stratified randomization, and restriction.

Other options:
Option A - Recall bias in case-control studies occurs because history recollection is better in the case group as they have a stronger exposure than the control group. This bias can be reduced by decreasing the recall period as much as possible.

Option C - Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D - Interviewer bias is a type of bias that occurs because the interviewer is aware of the case group and the hypothesis being tested, which can influence interviews and analysis. This can be reduced by blinding to reduce their influence on interviews and interpretation of outcomes.

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

Similarly:

  • 95% of population --- Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240
  • 99% of population --- Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

questions.text: As an intern posted in a PHC, you observe a public water tank disinfected with chlorine. Following this, an orthotolidine-arsenite test is performed. What is/are the parameters measured by this test?
questions.solution:
The parameters measured by the orthotolidine-arsenite test (OTA) are free and combined chlorine separately.

It is a modification of the orthotolidine test (OT), that measures free and combined chlorine levels together. (Option C)

In addition, the errors caused by the presence of interfering substances such as nitrites, iron and manganese, that produce yellow colour(positive)with an OT test are overcome by the OTA test.

The OT test is performed by adding 0.1 ml of the reagent containing orthotoludine dissolved in 10% hydrochloric acid to 1 ml of water to be tested. A yellow colour is produced which is matched against suitable standards or colour discs. Commercial equipment is available for this purpose. It is essential to take the reading within 10 seconds after the addition of the reagent to estimate free chlorine in water. The colour that is produced after a lapse of 15-20 minutes, is due to the action of both free and combined chlorine.

The chlorine demand is measured by Horrock’s apparatus. (Option A)

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: A patient comes with a ​history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution:
A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus:

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization
Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a principle of health education?
questions.solution:
Drawing conclusions is not a principle of health education.

Principles of Health Education:

(Mnemonic: PLS, Good Friend, CLICK MoRe!)

  • Participation
  • Learning by doing
  • Setting an example
  • Good human relations
  • Feedback
  • Credibility
  • Leaders
  • Interest
  • Comprehension
  • Known to unknown
  • Motivation
  • Reinforcement

NOTE: 'Known to unknown' means to start where the people are and with what they understand and then proceed to new knowledge.

questions.text: While testing the deleterious health hazards on a group of people after giving a new drug and a placebo, the following results were obtained as tabulated. Based on these results, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.1
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.9
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 10
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 9

questions.solution:
• Lets reconstruct the design table in the following way:
  Health hazard (+) Health hazard (-) Total
New drug 1603 (a) 13622 (b) 15225 (a+b)
Placebo 1804 (c) 13421 (d) 15225 (c+d)
  • Relative risk (RR) is given as a/(a+b) ÷c/(c+d).
  • In this scenario, RR = 1603/15225 ÷ 1804/15225 = 0.106/0.118 = 0.89, which is can be rounded up to 0.90. Thus RR = 0.90.
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = 1 – Relative risk. In this scenario, RRR = 1 – 0.9 = 0.1 or 10%.
  • Incidence of a disease is the absolute risk of contracting it.
  • Absolute risk rate of group using new drug = 1603/15225 = 0.106 or 10.6% = 11%. The absolute risk rate of group using placebo = 1804/15225 = 0.118 or 11.8% = 12%.
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo and the drug.
  • In this scenario, ARR = 12% - 11% = 1%.

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called as lead time.

Other options:

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text: The non-communicable disease (NCD)  clinic at the district hospital screens people above the age of 50 years with positive family history for diabetes.  What type of screening is this?
questions.solution:
The non-communicable disease/ NCD clinic at the district hospital screening people above the age of 50 years for diabetes is a type of high-risk screening. 

Screening is searching or testing for diseases or defects that are not evident in apparently healthy individuals. High-risk or selective screening is screening applied selectively to high-risk groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. For example, screening the other members in families of patients with diabetes or hypertension that tend to aggregate in families. It is an effective and economical method of screening.  

Other options:

Option A: Mass screening is the screening of a population or a sub-group of the population for a disease irrespective of the particular risk an individual may run of contracting the disease in question. It is not a useful preventive measure unless there is a  suitable treatment that alters the duration or outcome of a disease.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests (instead of carrying out separate screening tests for a single disease) to a large number of people in the form of health questionnaires, clinical examinations, and investigations. It has not shown any benefit to the population in terms of mortality and morbidity reduction and has instead increased the cost of health services.

Option C: Prospective screening is screening people for the benefit of others. For example, screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis to protect the home population from the disease.

Note: Prescriptive screening is defined as the presumptive screening of patients for unrecognized diseases for their own benefit. It usually does not arise from a patient's request. Examples include screening for bacteriuria in pregnancy and screening for hemolytic disease in a neonate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A newborn was visited by the ASHA worker of the community under the Home Based Neonatal Care until the baby was 42 days old. A total of how many visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home Based Care for Young Child?
questions.solution:
A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).

ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months. They will help promote early initiation of breastfeeding, exclusive breastfeeding till 6 months, and continued breastfeeding till 2nd year of life along with adequate complementary feeding and to ensure age-appropriate immunization and early childhood development.

ASHAs will be provided an additional incentive of Rs. 250 for the completion of 5 home visits under HBYC for each young child (Rs. 50 per visit). HBYC is being rolled out in a phased manner. 

Related Pearl: Suggested Norms for Health Workforce

Health Personnel

Norm Suggested

Doctor

1 per 1000 population

Health worker (Male and female)

1 per 5000 in plains

1 per 3000 remote or hilly areas

Health assistant (Male and female)

1 per 30,000 in plains

1 per 20,000 in remote or hilly areas

Pharmacist

1 per 10,000

Lab technician

1 per 10,000

Auxillary Nurse Midwife

1 per 10,000

Urban Social Health Activist

1 per 1000-2500

Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA)

1 per 1000 (a village, 200-500 households)

1 per habitation in remote or hilly areas

Trained Dais or Trained Birth Attendant

1 per 1000 (a village)

Village health guide (VHG)

1 per 1000 (a village)

Anganwadi worker (AWW)

1 per 400 to 800 in plains

1 per 300 to 800 in remote or hilly areas

Nurse

1 per 5000

Mahila Arogya Samiti

1 per 250-500 (50-100 households)

 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: What is the primary goal of the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme?

choices.text: To promote healthy lifestyle choices among individuals
To collect monthly disease surveillance data
To detect early warning signals of outbreaks
To conduct research on rare diseases

questions.solution:
The main purpose of Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) is to detect early warning signals of outbreaks.

IDSP (formely known as Integrated Disease Surveillance Project)  is a national decentralised state-based surveillance program. The mission is to detect early warning signals for timely and effective public health action so that it can be initiated against outbreaks of prone diseases in both urban and rural areas. It also provides essential data to monitor ongoing disease control programs. 

The program includes a Central Surveillance Unit, State Surveillance Units, and District Surveillance Units, and collects weekly disease surveillance data (Option B) on epidemic-prone diseases from reporting units such as hospitals and medical colleges. The data is analyzed for disease trends and investigated by a Rapid Response Team consisting of specialists whenever there is a rising trend of illness.

The surveillance is necessary to recognize cases or clusters of cases, access the public health impact of health events, demonstrate the need for public health intervention programs, monitor the effectiveness of prevention and control measures, and identify high-risk groups or geographical areas for targeted interventions.

questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a hypothetical population form two overlapping distributions, one of the people with diabetes(B), and another one of the people without diabetes(A) resembling those in the figure shown below. A test was done with the cutoff for diagnosing diabetes as 120mg/ dl, what does the area D represent?

choices.text: Diabetics correctly classified as the same
Non-diabetics correctly  classified as the same

questions.solution:
Area D represents the false positives (Non-diabetics incorrectly classified as diabetics)

Area C represents the False Negatives (Diabetics incorrectly classified as non-diabetics)

Area B represents the True positives (Diabetics correctly classified as the same) and the false negatives 

Area A represents the  True negatives (Non-diabetics correctly classified as the same) and the false positives 

Note :

From the above distribution curves, it is apparent that the choice of the cutoff point will determine the sensitivity and specificity of the test.

For example, reducing the cutoff to a lower value will increase the sensitivity, but the specificity will be low and the number of false-positive results will be unacceptably high. Similarly, by plotting on a distribution curve think of what would happen if the cutoff point is increased.

A test can only be 100% specific and 100% sensitive if there is no overlap between the curves, this kind of situation doesn't commonly occur and when it does, the disease may be so obvious that no diagnostic testing is required. Hence it is often best to use a combination of tests to diagnose a disease. A highly sensitive (usually relatively cheap) followed by a more specific test. 

 

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about systematic reviews?
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is not always performed in systematic reviews. 

Steps of a Systematic Review:

  • A systematic review is the process of locating and synthesizing the research on a particular question using organized, transparent, and replicable procedures.
  • It ranks high in the hierarchy of evidence in medicine.
  • The research question formulated is always focussed.
  • The literature on studies is always found and appraised after criteria of eligibility are established.
  • Meta-analysis is usually done in a systematic review but not always.

questions.text: During a rural outreach program, you interact with a 28-year-old female and her 2-year-old son. You notice that the mother appears lean and on examination find that she has pallor. Her son’s current weight for age is below the 50th percentile. Which national program would you educate these patients about?
questions.solution:
As the key issues identified in the mother and her son are anemia and malnutrition, they are part of the target population of the POSHAN Abhiyaan program.

The goals of the POSHAN Abhiyaan programme are:

  • Prevent and reduce undernutrition and stunting in children aged 0-6 years.
  • Reduce the prevalence of anemia among children aged 6 months - 6 years.
  • Reduce the prevalence of anemia among women and adolescent girls aged 15-49 years.
  • Reduce low birth weight.

Other Options:

Option A: The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

Option B: Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) seeks to empower adolescent girls, so as to enable them to take charge of their lives. The objectives are to:

  • improve the nutritional, health and development status of adolescent girls
  • promote awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition and family care
  • opportunities for learning life skills
  • going back to school
  • help them gain a better understanding of their social environment
  • take initiatives to become productive members of society.

Option D: Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government scheme in India to provide Rs.500 per month for TB patients to buy food.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Setting up of Health and Wellness centres
Health insurance coverage upto Rs 10 lakh per family per year
Treatment to all preexisting diseases are covered
Age appropriate health promotion at schools

questions.solution:
The health insurance coverage under Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission is upto 5 lakh per family per year

The primary aim of the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission is to build a comprehensive need-based health care service. 

Components: The target of the two initiatives mentioned below is to build a New India 2022.

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- These centers will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services.
  • The second component is the National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) which provides health protection coverage to poor and vulnerable families. The Health and Wellness Centres will play a critical role in creating awareness about AB-NHPM, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.
  • School health programs including age-appropriate health promotion, screening, supplementation of iron and folic acid tablets, health administration via health centres.

Benefits:

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the SECC database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number - 14555

questions.text: An epidemiologist describes a disease outbreak in a graph, as shown in the image below, based on the data received from field investigations. Which of the following could be the cause of such an outbreak?

choices.text: Outbreak of cholera due to contaminated well water
Toxic chemical poisoning from an industrial accident
Food poisoning from a lunch party

questions.solution:
The image shows the common source, multiple exposure epidemic. Among the given options an example of it is outbreak of cholera due to contaminated well water.

A common source, multiple exposure epidemic occurs when a group of people are repeatedly exposed to the same harmful source over an extended period, leading to a series of illness cases. This type of epidemic is characterised by multiple peaks in the incident cases, reflecting the ongoing exposure to the source.

Some examples include:

  • Legionnaires' disease from a hotel's water system
  • Gonorrhea from a sex worker
  Common source, single exposure Common source, multiple exposures 
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning from an event (option C), Toxic chemical poisoning from an industrial accident (option B) Sex worker infected with gonorrhea, Outbreak of cholera due to contaminated well water 

The epidemic of yellow fever (arthropod vector) is an example of a propagated epidemic (Option D) that result from transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Cases occur over more than one incubation period.  

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

questions.text: The government of India starts a new initiative where rehabilitation centres are opened across the country to support wounded soldiers from the army with medical and psychological aid. Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
The rehabilitation of wounded soldiers where they are in the late phase of pathogenesis falls under the tertiary level of prevention.

The tertiary level of prevention signifies intervention in the late pathogenesis phase. Tertiary prevention can be defined as "all measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, minimize suffering caused by existing departures from good health, and promote the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions".
