questions.text: Which of the following agency provides seed and manure in applied nutrition programs in schools?
questions.solution:
UNICEF provides seed and manure in applied nutrition programs in schools. 

Applied Nutrition Program is implemented with the aim of producing various types of productive food by the community for the community itself.

UNICEF assists the program by providing implements, seeds, manure, and water supply equipment. If free land is available in schools, the facilities provided by UNICEF should be used in developing school gardens.

The produce obtained from the gardens can be utilized for school feeding programs and for nutrition education. 

Another strategy called GOBI was also implemented by UNICEF with the aim of a child health revolution. 

The GOBI-FFF strategy was given by United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF).

  • The GOBI-FFF strategy is aimed at child health revolution and survival.
  • It was called initially called the GOBI strategy, and the FFF aspect was later added to it.

Other options:

Option A: CARE- Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere aims at providing food for children in the age group of 6-11 years. It is also helping in projects like integrated nutrition and health project, better health and nutrition projects, anemia control projects, etc.

Option B: UNDP- The United Nations Development Program provides funds for technical assistance. Its main objective is to help poorer nations in developing their human and natural resources. 

Option D: WHO- World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life. 

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the special programme for Research and Training in Tropical Disease (TDR) strategy of the WHO?
questions.solution:
The disease not included in the special programme for Research and Training in Tropical Disease is tick borne encephalitis.

The TDR is sponsored by the WHO, UNICEF, UNDP and World Bank.

The diseases included under this programme are:

  • Chagas disease
  • Dengue
  • Ebola
  • Helminthiasis
  • Leishmaniasis
  • Leprosy
  • Lymphatic filariasis
  • Malaria
  • Onchocerciasis
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Trypanosomiasis
  • Tuberculosis

The programme is sponsored by the WHO, UNICEF, UNDP, and World Bank.
World Neglected Tropical Diseases Day, observed annually on January 30th since 2021, promotes progress, unites efforts, and encourages action toward eliminating 20 tropical diseases that disproportionately affect underdeveloped regions. In 2024, the theme is "Unite. Act. Eliminate" encouraging global collaboration.

questions.text: Vaccination against which of the following organisms should be administered post-splenectomy?

choices.text: Haemophilus influenzae B, Staphylococcus aureus, Influenza

questions.solution:
All post-splenectomy patients need to be vaccinated against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenza type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years).

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations must be given at least 2 weeks before the elective surgery. In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

The following vaccines are given :

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine: A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. Revaccination is not needed for Hib.
  • Meningococcal vaccination: Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart. Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination: Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: The aim of Kyoto protocol is ______

choices.text: To promote clean water and sanitation.
To promote proper bio-medical waste disposal

questions.solution:
The aim of the Kyoto protocol is to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions.

The Kyoto Protocol is associated with the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) regime. It covers the emission of the following six greenhouse gases:

  • Carbon dioxide (CO2)
  • Methane (CH4)
  • Nitrous oxide (N2O)
  • Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs)
  • Perfluorocarbons (PFCs)
  • Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6)

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

  • Certain gases in the atmosphere absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after it has left the Earth’s surface
  • These gases are known as greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs)
  • These gases then emit longwave radiation in all directions, the downward going portion of which add to the radiation arriving at the Earth’s surface and raise the equilibrium temperature.
  • In this entire process, the Earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as Greenhouse effect.
  • The most important natural GHGs are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, tropospheric ozone and nitrous oxide and non-natural GHGs are chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
  • Stratospheric ozone is not harmful and doesn’t contribute to the greenhouse effect
  • Greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.
  • The Kyoto Protocol is an internal agreement linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change by which its Parties set internationally binding emission reduction targets. The Parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18 percent in period between 2013 and 2020.
  • The Paris Agreement central aim is to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change by keeping a global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, apdaptation and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • The Montreal Protocol is related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text:
Match the following thermometers with their applications.
Type of thermometer Application
1. Dry bulb thermometer  A. The mean radiant temperature
2. Globe thermometer  B. The cooling capacity of the working environment
3. Wet globe thermometer  C. Low air velocities
4. Kata thermometer  D. The air temperature
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, and 4-C.

A dry bulb thermometer is an ordinary thermometer used to measure the air temperature. It is mounted on the Stevenson screen for accurate readings.

A globe thermometer can be used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings. It is affected by both the air temperature and radiant heat.

A wet globe thermometer is used for measuring environmental heat. It exchanges heat with the surroundings by conduction, convection, evaporation, and radiation. The equilibrium temperature of the globe provides a comprehensive measure of the cooling capacity of the work environment.

A kata thermometer was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air. It was used to assess the indices of thermal comfort. Currently, it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities. 

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

  • A number of thermometers which employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.
  • These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.
  • The instruments used to measure air temperature are:
    • Dry bulb thermometers:
      • These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level
    • Wet bulb thermometers
      • These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.
    • Maximum thermometer
      • This is a mercury thermometer which has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb
    • Minimum thermometer
      • The liquid in this thermometer is spirit which has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it
    • Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer
      • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
      • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
      • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available
  • Globe thermometer:
    • It is used for the direct measurement of mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
    • It has a hollow metal bulb (6 inches diameter) which has a matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
    • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.
  • Kata thermometers:
    • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
    • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
    • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Identify the following logo:
questions.solution:
Option A: Cytotoxic Waste

Option B: Biohazard

Option C: Radiation

questions.text: There is an outbreak of buboes in the community. What is the vector responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The vector for bubonic plague is Xenopsylla cheopis. It is also called a rat flea. It also transmits murine typhus, chiggerosis, and hymenolepsis diminuta. It can be identified by the presence of a conical-shaped head, the presence of thorax, abdomen, and three pairs of legs. 

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with special stains like Wayson's stain. The reservoir of infections is wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, Tatera indica is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea, also called Xenopsylla cheopis.

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

Other options

Option B- Species Phlebotomus argentipes, belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Diseases caused by other species of sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

Below image shows sand fly

Option C- Ixodes ticks (hard ticks) transmit rocky mountain spotted fever, Russian spring-summer encephalitis, Colorado tick fever, tularemia, tick paralysis and human babesiosis.

Below image shows Ixodes tick

Option D- Female Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors for malaria and filariasis (not in India). They can be identified by the presence of spotted wings. When resting on a surface, they make an angle with the surface.

The below image shows anopheles mosquito.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: Which of the following services are provided under the program represented by the logo below?

choices.text: Quality antenatal care free of cost on 9th of every month
Free transport service between home and institution
Improve quality of care in labor room and maternal OTs
Safe motherhood services including IFA tablets, Td vaccination

questions.solution:
The logo represents Laqshya. It is an initiative launched by the government of India to improve the quality of care in the labor room and maternal OTs. 

Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care that is provided to the pregnant mother in the labor room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical colleges (MCs) besides district hospitals (DHs), high delivery load sub-district hospitals (SDHs), and community health centers (CHCs).

The initiative plans to conduct quality certification of labor rooms and also incentivize facilities to achieve the targets outlined. The goal of this initiative is to reduce preventable maternal and newborn mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in the labor room and maternity OT and ensure respectful maternity care. The complete logo of the program is shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Quality antenatal care (including investigations and drugs) is provided free of cost on the 9th of every month under Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA).

Option B: Free transport service from home to institution, between facilities in case of referral, and back to home is provided free of cost under the Janani-Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK). The main aim of JSSK is to provide no-expense delivery, including a cesarean section, to all pregnant women delivering in public health services.

Option C: Safe motherhood services including IFA tablets, Td vaccination are provided under the Vandematharam scheme which is a voluntary scheme.  It can be volunteered by an OBG specialist, lady doctor/ MBBS doctor, maternity home, or nursing home. The enrolled doctors are instructed to display the 'Vandemataram logo' at their clinic. The respective DMO will provide IFA tablets, OC pills, and Td injections to the Vandematharam doctors/ clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room after being evacuated from a collapsed building during an earthquake. He is unconscious and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. Imaging of the head reveals the following findings. Which color code will you triage him in?
questions.solution:
The CT scan finding of a biconvex lentiform hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines is suggestive of an extradural hematoma. With a GCS score of 8, the patient should be triaged as red as management requires emergency surgery. 

Triage is done based on a preliminary assessment of patients to determine the urgency of treatment. Patients are prioritized based on the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical treatment. It is particularly useful in case of mass casualties to prevent health facilities from getting overwhelmed. 

Red indicated a high priority of treatment or an immediate transfer to higher health facilities. These patients may survive if they receive timely medical intervention. 

An extradural hematoma with a GCS score of < or = 8 necessitates emergent surgery in the form of craniotomy, hematoma evacuation, and ligation of the injured vessel. Early surgery is associated with good neurological outcomes.

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife conducting a vaccination camp received 2 vaccine vials. One is a pentavalent vaccine and the other is an MR vaccine, which she opened on the day of the camp. She intends to reuse these vials by storing them in proper condition, at her next vaccination camp to be conducted in 2 weeks. What would you advise her regarding the re-utilization of these vials?

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.solution:
She can use the pentavalent vaccine and discard the MR vaccine.  According to the open vial policy, the pentavalent vaccine can be reused, whereas MR can not be reused. 

Open vial policy allows for the reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV and liquid pentavalent vaccine.

It is not applicable for BCG, measles, rotavirus vaccines and JE vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be use in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water.

Ensure all opened vials have recorded date and time of opening.

At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable.

All open vials of BCG, measles and JE must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete.

All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register.

Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: As an intern in the community medicine department, you are asked to study the various graphical representations of data. What is the following graph best used for?

choices.text: Correlating risk factors of a disease
Studying the periodic trends of disease over time

questions.solution:
The graph depicted is a Kaplan-Meir plot and the use of the graph is survival time analysis.

Survival time analysis includes studying of -

  • What is the survival time of patients with a given disease.
  • How does this survival time compare between two groups of patients given different treatments for the same disease.
  • Among those who survive up to a certain time, at what time or rate can they be expected to die.
  • What factors, such as risk factors or treatments, affect the survival time.

Despite its name, survival analysis can be used to help answer questions of this kind about any kind of event, not just death—such as how long it takes before a hip replacement fails, how long it takes before a patient has a second heart attack, or how long it takes for coronary stents to become re-stenosed.

Other options -

Option A: The line of best fit is used to express a relationship in a scatter plot of different data points as a straight line rather than multiple dots. It is an output of regression analysis and can be used as a prediction tool.

Option C: Scatter diagrams are used to correlate risk factors of the disease and present as positive correlation, negative correlation or no correlation. 

Option D: A line diagram is used to study the periodic trends of a disease over time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: The provision of 100% biodegradable sanitary napkins for Rs.1 per pad at Janaushadhi Kendras under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana is known as?
questions.solution:
Suvidha is the program aimed at the provision of 100% biodegradable sanitary napkins under Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana.

Low-cost hygienic oxy-biodegradable sanitary napkins were made available for Rs.1 per pad at over 7,900 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India. The program aims to ensure ‘Swachhta, Swasthya, and Suvidha' for underprivileged women and to improve menstrual hygiene practices throughout the country.

Other options:

Option B: Freedays is the provision of a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees by the ASHA worker through the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

Option C: Saathiya is a government initiative launched to provide a platform for communication regarding adolescent age-related health issues. Saathiya, meaning a good friend, are peer educators trained by the government with the help of the Saathiya salah mobile application. These Saathiyas act as a catalyst for generating demand for adolescent health services and imparting age-appropriate knowledge on key adolescent health issues to their peer groups.

Option D: Sabla is an empowerment scheme for adolescent girls of age group 11 to 18 years to improve their nutritional and health status under the Integrated child development services scheme (ICDS).

questions.text: The Sustainable Development Goals(SDG's) are under which health organisation?

choices.text: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

questions.solution:
Sustainable Development Goals(SDG's) are under the United Nations Development Programme.

SDG comprises of 17 goals and 170 targets for Agenda 2030.

The sustainable development goals adopted in 2015 aim to reduce the under 5 mortality to as low as 25 per 1000 live births by the year 2030.

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), also known as the Global Goals, were adopted by the United Nations in 2015 as a call to action to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure that by 2030 all people enjoy peace and prosperity.

It consists of 17 integrated sustainable development goals to be achieved by the year 2030 with priority being given to countries that are furthest behind. The SDGs are designed to end poverty, hunger, AIDS, and discrimination against women and girls.

SDG 3 deals with ensuring healthy lives and promoting wellbeing for all at all ages. The important sub-targets of SDG 3 are:

Sub-target Goal
3.1 Reduce global maternal mortality to <70/100,000 live births.
3.2
  • Reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12/1000 live births.
  • Reduce under 5 mortality to at least as low as 25/1000 live births.
3.3 End epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and neglected tropical diseases, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases
3.5 Prevention and treatment of substance abuse, narcotic abuse, and harmful use of alcohol.
3.7 Universal access to sexual and reproductive health care services, including family planning.
3.9 Substantially reduce deaths and illnesses due to hazardous chemicals and air, water, and soil pollution and contamination.

 Given below is an overview of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

questions.text: A family brings in their child who is suffering from diarrhoea to the PHC. Oral Rehydration Solution is not available currently. Which among the following options will you advise them till the ORS mixture is obtained?

choices.text: Give the child a mixture of 1 teaspoon of table salt and 2 teaspoons of sugar in 1 L of drinking water.
Give the child salted rice water or soup
Dilute the child's usual diet and feed him.

questions.solution:
Salted rice water or salted yoghurt drinks must be given when ORS is not available.

Many countries have designated recommended house fluids. Wherever possible these should include at least one fluid that contains salt. Fluids that do not contain salt are water in which a cereal has been cooked e.g. rice water; unsalted soup, yoghurt drinks, green coconut water, weak tea etc. The mothers should be taught to add salt about 3 g/litre to an unsalted drink or soup during diarrhoea

What do we advise the family to do when ORS is not available?

To- do:

  • If the WHO mixture is not available, a simple mixture of 1 teaspoon of table salt and 6 teaspoons of sugar must be dissolved in 1 L of drinking water and given to the child.
  • Add 3g/litre of salt to an unsalted drink or soup.
  • The infant's usual diet of cereals, vegetables and other foods should be continued and never be diluted. The child should be given as much nutrient-rich food as acceptable.

Avoid:

  • Sweetened drinks with sugar, like commercial fruit juices and sweetened tea, as they lead to osmotic diarrhoea and hypernatremia.
  • Fluids with a stimulant and purgative effect like coffee and medicinal tea infusions.

questions.text: Where is the DPT vaccine stored in an ice-lined refrigerator(ILR)?

choices.text: Stored in the lower zone as it is freeze sensitive
Stored in the upper zone as it is freeze sensitive
Stored in the upper zone as it is heat sensitive
Stored in the lower zone as it is heat sensitive

questions.solution:
DPT vaccine is freeze sensitive and hence stored in the upper zone of an ice-lined refrigerator(ILR).

ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centres. They are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like cholera, hep B, rotavirus(liquid), etc while the lower zone is for heat-sensitive vaccines like OPV, measles, etc. Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ILR.

Freeze sensitive vaccines

  • Cholera
  • DTaP-hepatitis B-Hib-IPV (hexavalent)
  • DIwP or DTwP-hepatitis B-Hib (pentavalent) Hepatitis B (Hep B)
  • Hib (liquid)
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • Inactivated poliovirus (IPV)
  • Influenza
  • Pneumococcal
  • Tetanus, DT, Td
  • Rotavirus (liquid and freeze-dried)

Related Pearl: Cold Chain Equipment

Cold chain equipment : 

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator

  • Solar Refrigerator Direct drive

questions.text: Which of the following is the requirement to give mass treatment for trachoma in a community?

choices.text: Prevalance of more than 5% of cases in adolescent age groups
Prevelance of more than 5% of cases in children of 1-9 years
Prevalance of more than 10% of cases in children of age 1-9 years
Prevalance of more than 10% of cases in adolescent age groups

questions.solution:
Prevalence of trachoma cases of more than 10% in children of age group 1-9 years is an important criterion to start mass prophylaxis of antibiotic treatment in the community according to the WHO program to control trachoma.

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children. They present with conjunctival follicles containing Leber cells and corneal Herbert's follicles.

The cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. The patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and finally loss of vision.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to which kind of carrier?
questions.solution:
Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to the convalescent carrier.

In cases of typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amebic), cholera, diphtheria, and whooping cough, patients continue to shed the disease agent during the period of recovery following an illness (convalescence). They pose a serious threat to unprotected household members and those in the immediate environment.

Other options:

Option A: Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for poliovirus.

Option B: Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period and can carriers transmit the disease before the onset of symptoms. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria, and hepatitis B.

Option D: Healthy carriers acquire the infectious agent but do not develop any symptoms of disease and keep shedding the agent. Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

questions.text: In a town, there are 2500 live births within 6 months. During the same period, 5 women died due to peripartum infection, 5 women died due to electrocution, 2 died due to obstructed labour and 3 died due to postpartum haemorrhage. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR)?
questions.solution:
The MMR in the above scenario is 400 per 100000 live births

MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period

In this scenario, only 10 women died due to causes related to pregnancy (5-peripartum infection,2- obstructed labour and 3-postpartum haemorrhage). Only they can be included in the statistics.

So, MMR here = 10 x 100000/2500 = 400 per 100,000 live births.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order of the demographic cycle.

1. Early expanding population

2. Declining population

3. Low stationary population 

4. Late expanding population

5. High stationary population
questions.solution:
The correct order according to the demographic cycle is high stationary population (5) --> early expanding population  (1) --> late expanding population (4) --> low stationary population (3) -->  declining population  (2).

The demographic cycle has 5 stages:

  • Stage 1: High stationary population 
  • Stage 2: Early expanding population 
  • Stage 3: Late expanding population 
  • Stage 4: Low stationary population 
  • Stage 5: Declining population

In a high stationary population, there is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

The early expanding population is marked by a decline in the death rate but the birth rate stays constant. Many countries in South Asia and Africa are in this phase. 

In the late expanding population there is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase. 

A low stationary population is characterized by low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

A declining population is one where the birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Examples include East European countries like Germany and Hungary.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman from a rural area registered in the scheme shown below. Which of the following benefits would she receive under this scheme?

choices.text: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 homebased newborn care visits
Free checkup on 9th of every month

questions.solution:
The above image shows the logo of Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA):

Benefit: Free checkup on the 9th of every month.

Objective: Improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services.

Implementation: Pregnant women receive at least one check-up in their second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, specifically on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different coloured stickers are pasted on mother and child protection cards.

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Other options:

Option A: Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY):

  • Benefit: Cash incentive of 5000 rupees.
  • Eligibility: Provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers for the first living child of the
  • family, subject to specific conditions.

Option B: Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN):

  • Benefit: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits.
  • Objective: Assured, dignified, and respectful delivery of quality healthcare services at no cost, aiming to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.
  • Implementation: Ensures zero tolerance for denial of services to any woman and newborn, providing antenatal checkups and home-based newborn care visits.

Option D: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY):

  • Benefit: Cash incentive of 1400 rupees.
  • Eligibility: Provided to all pregnant women who undergo institutional delivery in low-performing states.
  • Objective: Promote institutional delivery to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
• Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator.
  • DALY, HALE, and Sullivan’s Index belong to disability rates.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Crude death rate = ( Number of deaths during the year/Mid year population ) x 1000

Age specific death rate = ( Number of deaths in specific age groups/Mid year population of that age group ) x 1000

Sex specific death rate = ( Number of deaths per year of that sex/Mid year population of that sex ) x 1000

Case fatality rate = ( Total number of deaths due to a particular disease/Total number of cases due to same disease ) x 100

Proportional mortality from a particular disease = ( Number of deaths from a specific disease in a year/ Total deaths from all causes in a year ) x 100

Under 5 mortality rate = ( Number of deaths under 5 yrs of age in a year/Total live birth in that year ) x 1000

Survival rate = ( Total number of patients alive after 5 yrs /Total number of patients diagnosed or treated ) x 100
